title: Was it Lennon or McCartney who had the widest vocal range? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well they both have different ranges. Paul could sing higher notes more easily. He’s what I call a mid-range tenor, so he can’t really sing counter-tenor notes without losing tonal support. Like in “Say, Say, Say” you can tell that Paul’s vocal clearly isn’t designed to sing that high. Not like Michael Jackson. John can sing high notes that most baritones can’t reach without losing tonal support, but he’s only a high-range baritone so he can’t reach the same high notes that Paul can reach. At least not without losing tonal support. Paul had to sing the higher notes on “A Hard Day’s Night” and “Any Time at All” because John apparently couldn’t reach them. I’m pretty sure John could have reached those notes because he has reached higher notes at certain other points, but then again he probably wouldn’t have been able to sing them properly, which probably explains why Paul needed to sing them.

All those who said Paul are correct as Paul has one of the best ranges in music or at least he did at one time. His range was better than people that you would think have fantastic range like Michael Jackson and yet MJ’s range wasn’t even close to Paul’s. Oddly enough though MJ and Lennon had the same range vocally, of course they sang in different keys but the actual range span was the same. Paul’s range was very deceptive unless as a singer like myself you try and sing one of his songs with a lot of range only to discover you can’t pull it off.
